terms.definition: Software with source code that anyone can inspect, modify, and enhance. Often distributed under licenses like MIT, GPL, or Apache.
A pricing model where basic features are free, but advanced features require payment.
A limited version of a paid service available at no cost, often with usage restrictions.
Software you can run on your own servers, giving you full control over data and customization.
Services that can be used immediately without creating an account.
A service that encrypts your internet connection and masks your IP address for privacy and security.
The system that translates domain names (like google.com) into IP addresses that computers can understand.
Technology that prevents advertisements from loading on websites, improving privacy and page load times.
A security method where only the communicating users can read the messages, not even the service provider.
An extra layer of security requiring two forms of identification before granting access.
A set of rules and protocols for building and interacting with software applications.
A web API that follows REST architectural principles, using HTTP methods like GET, POST, PUT, DELETE.
A text-based interface for interacting with software and operating systems.
A storage location for software projects, often hosted on platforms like GitHub or GitLab.
Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment - automated building, testing, and deployment of code.
A permissive open-source license allowing nearly unlimited freedom with software use and distribution.
A copyleft license requiring derivative works to be distributed under the same license terms.
A permissive license similar to MIT but with explicit patent rights grants.
Software with restricted licensing where the source code is not publicly available.
An ethical hacking certification offered by OffSec that focuses on hands-on penetration testing skills.
A software vulnerability that is unknown to those who should be interested in its mitigation (including the vendor).
Short for penetration testing, a simulated cyberattack against your computer system to check for exploitable vulnerabilities.
A type of vulnerability where an attacker can interfere with the queries that an application makes to its database.
A security vulnerability typically found in web applications that allows attackers to inject client-side scripts into web pages viewed by other users.
A type of shell where the target machine communicates back to the attacking machine, allowing remote command execution.
The managing and provisioning of infrastructure through code instead of through manual processes.
A cloud-computing execution model where the cloud provider runs the server and dynamically manages the allocation of machine resources.
An open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.
A platform for developers and sysadmins to build, run, and share applications with containers.
An architectural style that structures an application as a collection of services that are highly maintainable and testable.
